data.title: Such a pretty room for lunch
data.text: We had the room mostly to ourselves...my husband had the soup and salad bar which was nice and i had the crab cakes which were good, not amazing but good...the ambiance was sooo nice tho and the staff VERY friendly...I am happy to recommend. If you are not a foodie, you'll love it. If you are...and I am a bit of a food snob...I think you will still quite enjoy lunch in such a beautiful spot.

data.title: Love, Love, Love
data.text: Great service, nice menu with creole-cajun flair.  A little pricey, but well worth it.  The décor is so old-Southern.

data.title: An Elegant Breakfast
data.text: Since we were staying at Le Pavillon, we reserved breakfast one morning at the Crystal Room. The room is absolutely gorgeous and very elegant. We ordered off the menu and both of our breakfasts were delicious. Our server, Dallas, was absolutely wonderful! So kind and caring. We thoroughly enjoyed our meal and the beautiful surroundings.

data.title: Faded Glory
data.text: Breakfast is served in a beautiful, ornate ballroom.  The food is quite good.  Excellent selections which reflect the location.  The problem is that everything just seems a bit tired.  The carpeting, the scuff marks on the wall, the ill fitting suits on the waiters.  The buffet breakfast looks downright inedible.  Order from the menu and be pleasantly surprised by the quality of the food.

data.title: Great dining experience!
data.text: My mother, wife and I enjoyed truly one of the best dining experiences in our lives. Exceptional service by Alvin , Lucy, Guadalupe, and  Ms. Patty Cake made dinner and breakfast most memorable.  The congenial personalities and a heartfelt personal attention is more than worthy to mention.  My mother (age 91) still talks about the experience daily. Thank you Crustal Room staff.   We'll be back!

data.title: Christmas Brunch was a horrific experience
data.text:
My girlfriend and I made reservations for the Christmas Champagne Brunch for 11:45.  Due to parking we arrived at 11:50, but we had called ahead.  There was a frazzled woman at the hostess desk but about 30 people in front of us and 30 people milling about looking angry.  She eventually just told us to go to the bar without taking our name.  She had a napkin in her hand with names on it so my girlfriend went back and gave out name and said we had a reservation.  The hostess said everyone had reservations, but wrote out names down and sent us back to the bar.  An hour later our name was called.  We went in to find it was a buffet...not advertised as one.  The meat cutting station was no manned.  The food was in warmers...about half were empty and cold.  The food was tasteless and bland.  Much was thrown away.  They 2 hours later they still had a line.  I have never seen so many angry patrons wanting to talk to management.  They had taken a credit card to charge if you didn't show.

We spoke with other patrons who had been coming for 10 years who said the management had changed and the chef had either quit of been fired.   Brunch was supposed to last until 2:30 but by 2:20 we were leaving having been seated after 1 PM.  They were clearing out the trays, but still seating people.  Others on Yelp had an Identical dinner expeience.

data.title: Christmas Ruined!! Or 27 Reasons to Avoid Le Pavillion at all costs.
data.text:
Let me first say that I have been a regular customer of the Crystal Room for more than a decade now and have enjoyed almost 20 Thanksgiving, Christmas, and Easter holidays at the hotel.  My patronage and unwavering support has now ended in the wake of the single most disastrous dining experience I have ever had.  Just one of the problems I experienced would be enough to aggravate even the most seasoned diner, but I experienced no less than 27 problems on this visit, some of which are so rare and offensive I am still struggling for the words to describe them.  I'll also say that I am not a fussy diner and the overwhelming majority of my reviews on Trip Advisor are positive as I generally like to use this platform to recommend rather than reject hotels and restaurants.  Without further adieu here are the reasons:
1.	A reservation could not be made by telephone in a timely manner because the person who answered the telephone was unable to make a reservation, twice.
2.	A credit card required to guarantee reservation on Open Table, which is kind of insulting given that I attempted to make reservations via telephone on two separate occasions which would not have required one.
3.	We arrived at 1:40pm for a 2:00pm reservation to find close to 100 people waiting in the lobby of the hotel to eat.  I knew I was in trouble at this point, but I was being held hostage as they already had my credit card number.
4.	The hostess immediately blamed the customers in the dining room for the delay.  She said people are taking longer than normal.  Who could have anticipated that people would linger at Christmas dinner?  I’m pretty sure that everyone with half of a brain could have anticipated that.
5.	Numerous tables were open and set and many more needed to be cleared.  None of those tables ever had customers seated at them over the course of my 3 ½ hour stay.  
6.	The hostess abandoned computerized reservation system and scrawled my name on a slip of receipt paper.  This was not the result of a computer crash and no one was able to explain to me how or why this was happening.  It is totally inexplicable, but it happened.
7.	I later learned that the hostess started seating whoever was in front of her and completely ignoring times of reservations or party sizes.
8.	After being told to wait in the hotel lobby no hostess or employee ever came to the lobby to call for any party, not just my party but any party at all.
9.	The hostess refused to give me a wait time.  She refused to even tell me a ball park figure or the time of the reservations of those currently being seated.
10.	No bartender was ever available at bar when I tried to get my wife a drink.  Waited for 10 minutes and 15 minutes and never saw one.  I did see two waiters pouring themselves drinks from the soda gun and both promised to get the bartender but none ever came.
11.	Never able to check with hostess as she was never at the stand on the four separate occasions that I attempted to check with her.
12.	A hotel employee repeatedly lied to me about why the wait was so extreme and the time of the reservations of the other guests that had been seated before my wife and I.  She kept saying “they are just a little backed up today” which isn’t actually possible given that this was a buffet.  How does the kitchen get behind at a buffet? 
13.	After the hostess was retrieved by another employee for me one hour and 20 minutes into my wait.  She said she would seat me and then disappeared into the dining room to never be seen again.
14.	The restaurant manager then told me at 3:15 (one hour and 35 minutes into my wait) that her advice is that I not even eat at the Crystal Room due to what she described as “challenges.”
15.	The manager then suggested that we eat elsewhere and that they would pay for my meal, but when I asked where that meal would be she was unable to offer even one suggestion of where that meal might take place.
16.	After offering for me to order from their a la carte menu the manager then sat me at a table next to buffet stations that were being disassembled.  I can only assume so that I could see what I was missing, or wanted the staff to have an audience while they carted off the dregs of the buffet.  Numerous other tables were available in that were not in the work zone of the buffet.
17.	We were offered complimentary champagne which was served hot, not warm or room temperature, but hot like it had been stored in a boiler room.  It was undrinkable even to two people who had been trying to get a drink for two hours. 
18.	Our waitress took 15 minutes to bring us menus for a la carte dining before disappearing for another 15 minutes.  This is in a restaurant that is fully staffed, half full, and serving a buffet.
19.	My wife then ordered crab cakes and a steak from the menu and I ordered a salad and a club sandwich.  My wife was more optimistic than I at this point and I figured we are finally going to get something to eat, but I was right, they screwed up this seemingly simple order.
20.	20 minutes later the waitress returned to tell me that they were out of crab cakes.  When I asked what they could provide as an alternative she suggested that we look at a menu again.  I refused and advised her to cancel the rest of the order.  Actually I am fairly certain that the waitress could not speak or understand English at a level that would allow her to hold a job where she has to interact with the English speaking public.  I got a lot of blank stares.
21.	We then ate random scraps of leftovers from a buffet that was sitting out for at least 5 hours as I was convinced that it was the only way that we would get anything to eat.  
22.	The food later gave both my wife and I tremendous gastrointestinal distress making this not only one of the worst experiences I have ever had at any hospitality establishment it actually followed us home and continued into the next morning.
23.	Our a la carte order that had been cancelled 30 minutes earlier arrived at our table.
24.	The $12 Ceaser Salad was the saddest, most wilted, most pathetic salad I have been served anywhere but a fast food restaurant.  Wendy’s has a better ceaser, but they are closed on Christmas so I could not go get one.
25.	My wife’s steak was ordered medium-rare but was served at a temperature best described as well-ruined, hockey puck like, or inedible.
26.	The manager who had previously promised to personally take care of us finally reappeared and promised that the General Manager would be contacting me to discuss our experience.  That never happened.
27.	All of this madness went on despite the fact that the hotel and restaurant both appeared to be fully staffed.  There must have been at least 40 wait staff present, but they all seemed to be hiding from the customers rather than trying to serve anyone.
And on a final note all of this occurred on my wife's birthday at an establishment that I had been touting as one of the finest holiday dining experiences one could have.  Thank you Pavillon for ruining two special occasions for the price of one.

data.title: Fine Dining in Elegant Setting
data.text: On a visit to New Orleans, my wife and I were looking to find a nice restaurant to celebrate her birthday.  She did some research and liked the photos of this hotel/restaurant.  The first impression we got as we departed from the cab was spectacular!  The restaurant is in a white mansion that is now a hotel.  A doorman in a derby greeted us and led us to the restaurant.  The ceilings are very high and the walkway to the restaurant was furnished with what appeared to be antiques with a setting of the late 1800s.  We were seated by the fireplace which added to the atmosphere of eating in a by gone era. My wife order drum fish (similar to redfish) and I ordered the beef tips over noodles.  My wife’s fish was excellent, but mine was average.  I must say my Manhattan was excellent, however.  We were celebrating my wife’s birthday so to our surprise the chef came out and talked to my wife and our server provided us a complimentary dessert with a personalized message (Look at the photos to see it.)  Our server also took several photos of us dining and in front of the fireplace so we have memories for later.  Overall, we had a very enjoyable and memorable dinner.  I thought the value was reasonable for downtown New Orleans and very good for the beautiful atmosphere they maintain here.

data.title: Warm Southern Charm
data.text: The Crystal Room offers service with a warm southern hospitality and with the culinary talents of Chef Mendoza your palate is taken to new heights. Chef Mendoza offers an amazing Sunday Brunch from omelets of your choice made before your eyes, to shrimp and crab legs, to prime rib and salmon.  Several trips to the buffet were taken so we could get a sampling of all this Chef has to offer. One also needs to experience dinner, from seafood to filet to gumbo with the ambiance of the fire place and attentive staff you are taken back in time to a time of gentility.  The prime rib just melts away,  the gumbo gives one the taste of New Orleans, and the salmon was out of this world. Chef Mendoza I hear is working on a new menu and knowing that in itself makes one want to travel back to New Orleans to sample this Chef's tantalizing cuisine.  We have also mentioned Chef Mendoza's staff.  We would like to mention  a few dining staff that have warm, wonderful, and attentive personalities that offer service with a smile and want your dining experience to be over the top, and they are Frank and Jyllian.  Frank offers true southern hospitality and treats all guests like royalty.  Jyllian takes care in seeing that all guests are treated like family and that ones dining experience is complete from start to finish.  And in the bar area we have Pam.  Pam's sincere, outgoing and fun personality make for a wonderful close to one's day.  It was a pleasure speaking with Chef Mendoza, Frank, Pam and Jyllian who are a rare finds in customer service today in that they treat all guests with hospitality, kindness and friendliness and are an asset to the LePavillion family.

data.title: Excellent breakfast
data.text: Breakfast buffet and omelet station were both excellent. Frank was so attentive and so much fun, We really enjoyed the entire experience.
